metadata.title: Breast Cancer  Breast-Conserving  Surgery
anatomical location body part affected: Breast; lymph nodes in some cases
description: Breast cancer is a malignant disease of the breast tissue that typically occurs in women(1)

Breast-conserving  surgery is a treatment option for some women with localized breast cancers. Tumor size; breast size; multifocality; fixation to chest wall, skin, or nipple; scleroderma (reaction to radiation); and prior therapeutic radiation of ipsilateral breast or chest wall are all considered in surgery type decision(7)

Breast cancer is classified as follows:(12) –Carcinoma in situ is noninfiltrating (noninvasive) carcinoma, stage 0; cancer cells are contained and have not spread to any other part of the body –Infiltrating (invasive) carcinoma, stages I–IV;  cancer cells spread beyond the basement membrane of the mammary duct or lobule to adjacent breast parenchyma -The early stages of breast cancer are classified as stages I, IIA, or IIB based on the American Joint Committee on Cancer Tumor Node Metastasis (TNM) staging system -No tumor extension to the chest wall or skin -Can include moveable ipsilateral axillary lymph node metastases -No distant metastases -Locally advanced breast cancer is classified as stage IIIA, IIIB, or IIIC -Metastases in ipsilateral axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted -Metastases clinically detected within the internal mammary lymph nodes -Tumor is > 5 cm -Tumor present with direct extension to the chest wall and skin -Stage IV breast cancer is classified as advanced -Distant metastases

Types of breast cancer –Mammary duct cancer -Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)–  noninfiltrating (noninvasive) carcinoma, but there is a chance of disease progression/spread; considered stage 0(1) -Infiltrating (invasive) ductal carcinoma – the most common form of breast cancer; occurs in 50–70%  of all invasive breast cancers(22) –Mammary lobule cancer -Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) – noninfiltrating carcinoma, rarely will become invasive; considered stage 0(1) -Infiltrating (invasive) lobular carcinoma – ~ 10% of patients with breast cancer have this type(22)  –Inflammatory breast cancer(22) -Rare form -Patient typically finds the breast becomes red and swollen initially versus detection of a lump as in other forms of breast cancer –Paget’s disease of the breast(22) -Affects the nipple

This clinical review focuses on breast-conserving  surgical treatment for breast cancer. For a general overview of surgical treatment for breast cancer, please see Clinical Review…Breast Cancer: Surgical Treatment , CINAHL Topic ID number T708758

Breast-conserving  surgical treatment of breast cancer involves removal of the cancer but not the breast itself. The decision to proceed with breast-conserving  surgery can only be made after the cancer is staged –Breast-conserving  surgery has been shown, in several clinical trials, to result in survival rates similar to those for patients who undergo modified radical mastectomy for early (stage I or II) breast cancer(5) –Lumpectomy – surgeon excises tumor and minimal healthy tissue surrounding lesion; may also include a lymph node dissection(1) –Partial mastectomy or segmental mastectomy – portion of the breast is removed that encompasses cancerous tissue as well as a margin of tissue surrounding the cancerous area; may also include a lymph node dissection(1) -Technically a lumpectomy is a partial mastectomy, since part of the breast tissue is removed(2) -Quadrantectomy – type of partial mastectomy in which approximately one quarter of the breast is removed; excision of the tumor and surrounding tissue may include overlying skin and some chest wall fascia and muscle. Local lymph nodes are removed. Axillary dissection may or may not be included –A lumpectomy can be done under local anesthetic if lymph nodes are not being removed. General anesthesia is used for partial or segmental mastectomies or quadrantectomies –Breast-conserving  surgery typically is followed by radiation therapy; this treatment combination is referred to as breast-conserving  therapy (BCT) -Whole-breast  radiation is the standard of care following lumpectomy and is referred to as local BCT when combined with axillary staging with sentinel node biopsy or axillary dissection(4) -However, some experimentation has been done with not including radiation after lumpectomy in patients with stage I and II breast cancer. The 2014 National Comprehensive Cancer Network listed whole-breast radiation after lumpectomy as a stage I recommendation and lumpectomy without radiation as a stageIIB recommendation(5) -Patients for whom radiation therapy is contraindicated (e.g., those who are pregnant) are not ideal candidates for lumpectomy –Lymph node dissection may or may not be required with breast-conserving  surgery
indications: Breast-conserving  surgery in early stages of breast cancer may be chosen rather than mastectomy in order to save the breast –Major advantages are superior cosmetic results and reduced psychological and emotional trauma compared to mastectomy –The vast majority of women with stage I or II breast cancer are good candidates for BCT. Only about 50% of women with stage I or stage II breast cancer have BCT, however, despite evidence that it is a safe and effective alternative to mastectomy(10) -A joint study of the American College of Radiology and the American College of Surgeons found that high mastectomy rates in the United States are the result of inappropriate use of medical selection factors (e.g., tumor size, grade, node status) and a function of demographics(10) –Breast-conserving  surgery is not indicated in the following conditions:(11) -Previous radiation therapy in the breast/chest area -Two or more cancerous areas present within the same breast -Tumor is large relative to a smaller-sized  breast -Connective tissue disease(s) that are sensitive to radiation therapy -Pregnancy at the time of radiation therapy following surgery -Tumor size larger than 2 inches that does not decrease in size following chemotherapy -Residual tumor left from previous breast-conserving surgery

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. In the United States, the Women's Health and Cancer Rights Act (WHCRA) of 1998 mandates that all medical insurance providers, including Medicare, cover breast reconstruction after mastectomy. Under this law, benefits must also cover treatment of any physical complications  at all stages of mastectomy, including lymphedema.(13) Partial mastectomy including lumpectomy is included under the WHCRA
presentation signs and symptoms: Presentation varies depending on the extent of the surgery and can include the following:(3) –Lymphedema–  swelling of the arm due to lymph node removal -Early symptoms include a feeling of tightness in the arm, pain, redness, and decreased flexibility of the arm, hand, and wrist –Pain (acute and chronic) -Pain in the shoulder and cervical muscles, and at and surrounding the surgical site –Postural deviations (e.g., forward shoulders are common in postsurgical patients who are trying to avoid pain and a sensation of skin tightness)(2) -Fewer frontal plane postural deviations are seen with BCT when compared to mastectomy(14) –Prolonged healing of surgical site secondary to radiation therapy –Psychological impact (depression, anxiety, lowered self-esteem) –Reduced shoulder ROM –Reduced upper extremity and trunk strength –Decreased upper extremity functional mobility Causes, Pathogenesis, and Risk Factors (Breast Cancer)
contraindications precautions to test: Clinician should confirm and follow any physician orders/restrictions, including those with regard to lifting/straining
Clinician should ensure the involved upper extremity is not placed in a dependent position for extended periods(3)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
These patients are at increased risk for DVT: monitor for signs and symptoms and refer back to physician as indicated

overall contraindications precautions: Postoperatively, patients may experience pain at the incision site, in the shoulder girdle, and in the posterior cervical muscles. Pain may be the result of tension along the incision or spasms resulting from muscle guarding. This pain can lead to decreased use of the upper extremity and subsequent capsular restrictions and/or lymphedema(3)

Notify physician if any of the following occur postoperatively: Fever and/or chills Redness, swelling, or bleeding or other drainage from the incision site Increased pain around the incision site Swelling or numbness and/or tingling of the affected arm if lymph nodes have been removed
Patients are at increased risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pneumonia

Guidelines from the American Cancer Society on physical activity during and after treatment are as follows:(6) Persons with severe anemia should delay activity until anemia is improved Those with a weakened immune system should avoid public gyms and other public locations until white blood cell count returns to normal, safe levels Persons who are undergoing radiation therapy should avoid swimming pools because of the chlorine content, which may irritate the skin

After breast surgery that involved lymph node dissection, the patient should be encouraged to:(3) take breaks when traveling for extended distances (getting out of the vehicle and ambulating a bit is helpful in promoting circulation) support the impaired extremity during travel as able keep sodium ingestion to a minimum and strive to sustain ideal body weight don compression garments prior to exercise have blood pressure taken on the uninvolved arm monitor skin closely and attend to blisters, burns, insect bites, cuts, or abrasions keep skin clean and avoid lotion with perfume use an electric razor wear sun-protective  clothing outdoors avoid waxing and electrolysis

Patients who have had axillary lymph node dissection should not:(3) wear restrictive clothing or tight jewelry use local heat or spend time in hot environments use heavy weights with exercise participate in vigorous activity with the impaired extremity allow injections, blood draws, or blood pressure to be taken in the involved extremity, as able allow skin contact with harsh chemicals/detergents raise the body’s core temperature (in whirlpools, saunas, or hot baths) maintain fixed and dependent positions of the legs cross lower extremities while sitting
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
These patients are at increased risk for DVT: monitor for signs and symptoms and refer back to physician as indicated

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When was breast cancer diagnosed and what type? Identify the specific surgical procedure performed and its extent. Was there lymph node involvement? Was axillary lymph node dissection performed? Were there any metastatic lesions? Have there been any surgical complications?

course of treatment.medical management: Determine the patient’s specific course of medical management. The treatment approach to breast cancer often involves surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and hormone therapy(1) Authors of a 2020 systemic review and meta-analysis  found that a pectoral nerve block (Pecs) in combination with general anesthesia can result in lower pain scores and less opioid consumption for patients who are undergoing breast cancer surgery(16) Based on 13 RCTs in which 940 patients were included in the study Chemotherapy may be given first in order to shrink the tumor to a size that is compatible with breast-conserving surgery After breast-conserving  surgery, the standard treatment is whole-breast  radiation therapy, usually on a daily basis, for 3 to 6 weeks. Some patients may follow breastconserving  surgery with radiation therapy and chemotherapy, partial breast irradiation, or intraoperative radiotherapy with electrons. Women need to be counseled on the risks of each treatment option
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken? May include chemotherapy, hormonal/endocrine therapy (tamoxifen [Nolvadex]), bisphosphonates, and medications (gabapentin, venlafaxine) for hot flashes. Inquire about any medications for postoperative pain management. Are they being taken? Are they effective? Providing patients with gabapentin preoperatively has been shown to reduce acute and chronic postoperative pain and overall total morphine consumption and feelings of nausea in patients following breast cancer surgery(21)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Comprising mainly mammography, physical examination, ultrasound, and biopsy; further medical testing may be completed after cancer detection (e.g., bone scan, MRI) and to monitor health during chemotherapy and radiation therapy (e.g., cytology for immunosuppression and anemia)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture), what symptom they are used for, and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any activities, positions, etc., that aggravate or ease the patient’s symptoms following surgery
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant versus intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Pain is common following breast cancer treatment, including surgery(22)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Lymphedema may occur soon after surgery or years later
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Ask about sleeping positions -Postoperatively, women may choose to wear a supportive bra day and night for a while to minimize any movement that could cause pain. Women with larger breasts might find it more comfortable to sleep on the nonoperative side with the healing breast supported by a pillow -If the patient is experiencing shoulder pain, does the pain wake her at night? Is she able to find a comfortable position in which to sleep?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician, including warmth, redness, and pain in the breast and surrounding tissue indicative of infection or cellulitis. Inquire about any signs of lymphedema, including increased size of the extremity, tautness of skin, decreased ROM, and stiffness in the hand(2)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Is there any respiratory compromise? Does the patient require the use of supplemental oxygen?  Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient previously had breast cancer? Or another type of cancer? If yes, how was it treated? Does the patient have a history of shoulder dysfunction? Prior radiation therapy in the same breast precludes breast-conserving  surgery. Recurrence typically is treated with a mastectomy, not a second breastconserving  surgery
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cardiopulmonary disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Note hand dominance. What do the patient’s work, recreational, or household responsibilities require? Are these responsibilities being adversely affected by effects of BCT?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Did the patient previously utilize assistive/adaptive equipment?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Complete a general assessment as indicated with a focus on the items listed below
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –May take circumferential forearm measurements 5 cm and 10 cm below distal border of lateral epicondyle of humerus to assess for lymphedema. Lymphedema is swelling into surrounding tissue when lymphatic fluid can no longer travel effectively through a segment of the lymphatic system(2) –An alternative to girth measurement is volume measurement. The involved extremity is immersed in a tank of water up to an anatomical landmark and the volume of water displaced is measured(3) –Measure height and weight and calculate BMI
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance in sitting and standing. Use the Berg Balance Scale
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess and monitor vital signs (blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation levels)
Do not take BP on affected arm

Assess endurance with 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT). Use a dyspnea scale or the Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale •Ergonomics/body mechanics:  Proper body mechanics are important when recovering from breast cancer surgery in order to avoid putting undue strain on the incision(s) and traumatized structures. Observe the patient during mobility and note atypical compensatory strategies; perform ergonomic assessment of workstation if applicable •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.): Is the patient able to perform functional mobility tasks independently? FIM can be used for standardized assessment. Assess bed mobility and transfers. Depending on the surgical procedure, there may be protocols put in place by the surgeon/facility to guide mobility postoperatively
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Note gait deviations, need for assistance, and need for assistive device. Observe posture with ambulation. Assess gait safety with DGIAssess mobility of glenohumeral joint, scapula, thoracic spine, and cervical spine as indicated; assess glenohumeral rhythm during upper extremity motionAssess upper and lower extremity coordination as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: If cleared by surgeon, perform manual muscle testing for all shoulder movements. Assess overall bilateral upper extremity strength and trunk/abdominal strength. Assess grip strength using hand-grip  dynamometer
observation inspection palpation includi: Visually inspect and palpate the skin of the affected extremity
Note changes in the skin, wounds, scars, and color. Document size, location, and mobility of scars. A photograph may be beneficial(4)
Assess for signs and symptoms of DVT
Assess incision site and observe scar for adhesion or keloid formation
Document presence of edema and assess for pitting(3)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess for postural deviations. Shoulder protraction and thoracic rounding (flexion) can occur postoperatively. The patient may also experience asymmetrical positioning of the scapula and trunk(3) –Researchers in Poland compared the frontal plane posture in 101 patients with breast cancer before and 1 year after BCT or mastectomy and found that, although postural abnormalities occurred in both groups, the abnormalities were greater in the mastectomy group(14)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess PROM in cervical spine, trunk, and upper extremities. Shoulder ROM limitations are common following operative management in patients with breast cancer(3,4)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes in biceps and brachioradialis muscle tendons and triceps muscle tendonItems to test include combing hair, brushing teeth, and fastening a bra hook. Note ability to perform independently. Objective measures that may be used include the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) or the Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Evaluate light touch, two-point discrimination, and proprioception in affected upper extremity; compare to noninvolved extremity. Breast sensation can be affected by breast-conserving  surgery but is generally less affected than with mastectomy. Altered sensation in the breast can either be a reduction in sensation or over-sensitivity
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy – Breast (FACT-B) questionnairephysical, social, emotional, and functional, and one subscale specific to breast cancer

contraindications precautions: Cardiac arrhythmias may develop following chemotherapy; avoid aerobic activity for 12 days post treatment(3)

Electrodes should not be placed over: -the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators -the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region in pregnant women -carotid bodies -phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators -areas of known peripheral vascular disease including arterial or venous thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -areas of active osteomyelitis -areas of hemorrhage

Electrotherapy should be used with caution -in patients without intact sensation -in patients who are unable to communicate -in patients with compromised mental status -in patients with cardiac dysfunction -in patients with epilepsy
Electrodes should not be placed -over neoplasms -over compromised skin -over tissues vulnerable to hemorrhage or hematoma -over the cervical or craniofacial regions
other: If drains are in place, ROM typically should not surpass 90° of shoulder flexion/abduction(3)

Lymphedema therapy should be discontinued if arm circumference or pain increases. For more detailed information see Clinical Review…Lymphedema ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708532 and Clinical Review…Lymphedema Following Surgical Treatment for Breast Cancer , referenced above

Electrotherapy contraindications  (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(8)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital as well as physician’s orders. The treatment summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Breast-conserving  surgery and radiation therapy for breast cancer resulting in pain, musculoskeletal impairments, and/or loss of function. It is physically and psychologically beneficial that patients return to pre-surgical  function as quickly as possible
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out True shoulder pathology DVT versus lymphedema
prognosis: Prognosis for successful treatment is greater with early detection of breast cancer, before it has moved beyond the breast
Most breast surgeries are considered low-morbidity  procedures

The cosmetic outcome following standard wide local excision is suboptimal in 20–25%  of cases.(11) Suboptimal outcomes occur more often under the following conditions:(11) –Tumor is over 10–20%  of the breast volume –Tumor is situated in the medial pole of the breast
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Oncologist – refer back to oncologist as indicated for new symptoms Occupational therapist – for a decline in ADLs Psychologist/psychiatrist/counselor – as requested by patient or indicated by patient’s demeanor Breast cancer support groups Physician/pain management specialist for intractable pain
other considerations: There are many alternative therapy options to ease the discomforts of treatment for the patient with breast cancer –Based on a systematic review and meta-analysis,  acupuncture therapy can reduce breast-cancer-related  lymphedema in patients who have recently undergone breast cancer surgery(19)
It has been reported that the cosmetic and psychological results of BCT are better than with mastectomy; however, patients have not reported a better quality of life

Researchers in Greece who examined the long-term  quality of life of 155 patients with breast cancer who underwent breast-conserving surgery using the FACT-B  identified losses over time of functional and emotional well-being,  but improvements in patients’ physical well-being  and in patients’ social/family well-being(15)
treatment summary: Clinical practice guidelines have been formulated by the American Physical Therapy Association for breast-cancer-related lymphedema(20) –Early postoperative care -Resumption of activity should be coordinated with the interdisciplinary care team.Individualized exercise activitycan be increased as patient tolerated, while monitoring for any adverse effects -Compression garments should be fitted for patients with a high risk of developing lymphedema. Upper extremity exercises in combination with diaphragmatic breathing may help reduce lymphedema –Exercise for individuals with an International Society of Lymphology (ISL) score of 0(Subclinical Phase) -For those who are in the subclinical phase of lymphedema -Subclinical is defined as disease that is not considered severe enough or presenting with any observable symptoms -Progressive resistance training exercises are considered safe and should be initiated no later than1-month  postsurgery -An individualized aerobic exercise program should be performed -Assess exercise tolerance and capacity weekly and monitor for adverse effects –Interventions recommended for those with ISL Stage I (Early Lymphedema) -Patients should be properly fitted with a compression garment. Exercise should be individually tailored –Interventions for individuals with breast-cancer-related lymphedema  -If early signs of lymphedema are present, patients should be properly fitted for a compression garment and given an appropriate exercise program -For moderate to late stages of lymphedema (ISL stages II and III) -Stage II is defined as moderate lymphedema -Stage III is defined as having late stages of lymphedema -Compression bandages and exercises should be performed -Kinesiology tape can be applied but should not replace compression garments. Observe for any adverse effects associated with kinesiology tape application -Self-performed  manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) should be initiated once an appropriate stable volume reduction is achieved in the upper extremity. Continue using compression garment and exercise as appropriate

Complete decongestive physical therapy –The overall goal is to improve drainage of the obstructed areas and to push the fluids to unobstructed areas(3) –Early complete decongestive physical therapy is more effective than education alone in preventing lymphedema related to surgical treatment for breast cancer(9) -Based on an RCT of 120 women in Spain who had breast cancer surgery involving lymph node dissection -The women in the physical therapy group received complete decongestive physical therapy initiated 5 days after surgery and continued 3 days a week for 3 weeks -The women in the education group received only lymphedema education during the same time frame as the women in the physical therapy group

Therapeutic exercise –Authors of a systematic review found that a ROM and strengthening exercise program improves shoulder mobility in patients who have undergone breast cancer surgery, including flexion, abduction, and external rotation (18) -One thousand seven hundred ten patients were included in the study -Exercise protocols consisted of upper limb active exercises, passive and active stretching of the shoulder, and shoulder ROM and strengthening exercises, combined with scar tissue massage

Authors of a meta-analysis  found that cognitive behavioral therapy can improve the emotional states of women who have undergone breast cancer surgery by changing their cognitive schemas(17) –Forty-five  studies met inclusion criteria . decrease or eliminate lymphedema: Circumferential or volumetric measurements of upper extremities
improved rom, strength, and function in: Goniometric measures of upper limb ROM
improved quality of life: Patient-reported  outcome measures such as Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy for Breast Cancer (FACT-B)  orBreast-Related  Symptoms Questionnaire (BRSQ)

maintenance or prevention: Following primary therapy, patients with breast cancer require follow-up  by the physician so that recurrences can be detected and the opposite breast can be properly monitored
